Speaker.hpid: MR. DE VALERA MR. DE VALERA
Speaker.P: I would prefer to raise the question on the Home Affairs report, and let the financial part go ahead. The ultimate responsibility for order in this country rests on the Minister for Home Affairs of Dáil Eireann, as far as we are concerned, and as far as the Irish people who put us in office are concerned. It is our duty to know what is the policy of the Minister for Home Affairs in connection with the matter. It is not enough simply to say: “Wait and see.”

Speaker.hpid: MR. SEAN ETCHINGHAM MR. SEAN ETCHINGHAM
Speaker.P: We have not got an answer to a very simple question. The Minister for Home Affairs can answer the question. Has he employed this man, Kearney, the hunter of Roger Casement, in connection with the new police force?

Speaker.hpid: MR. E.J. DUGGAN MR. E.J. DUGGAN
Speaker.P: There is a police committee at work but I do not know the names or the records of many of the gentlemen on it; if anyone likes to put down a question I will enquire. I cannot answer the question at the moment.

Speaker.hpid: MR. A. STACK MR. A. STACK
Speaker.P: But you can discuss the policy of the Department.

Speaker.hpid: MR. FINIAN LYNCH MR. FINIAN LYNCH
Speaker.P: Is this the Dáil Department or the Department of the Provisional Government? Is the Dáil Department empowered to form a police force in substitution for the R.I.C. or the D.M.P.? I do not believe they have any power to do so.

Speaker.hpid: THE ACTING SPEAKER THE ACTING SPEAKER
Speaker.P: Once again I may mention that, according to the Standing Orders, any question can be raised by Deputies if they only hand in the question to the Minister concerned. There seems to be no limit to the number of questions that may be asked; but these questions must relate to matters of fact, or matters of policy. I hold under that, that any of the questions now asked may be put properly and answered if they are handed in, so that the Ministers can be prepared with a reply.

Speaker.hpid: MR. DE VALERA MR. DE VALERA
Speaker.P: It is a question of debating a policy. The natural place would be on the reports which, in past Sessions, were furnished by the heads of the various Departments. There is no such report here. I was anxious to know if we would have an opportunity for debate. There is no debate on a question. This whole question of the maintenance of order during three months, or for a longer period, is very important. I have no doubt the President and Ministry have a definite policy, and it is only right that we should know what that policy is. All these things are important for us, because it is our duty to see order kept in the country. I agree this must be a non-political police force. Of course, it must be, and I believe there is only one body can set that up, and that is this assembly.

Speaker.hpid: PRESIDENT GRIFFITH PRESIDENT GRIFFITH
Speaker.P: I want to be quite clear. I want the public to remember again that at the last Session we asked Mr. de Valera and his friends to co-operate with us in forming a Committee of Public Safety for the purpose of keeping order. That offer was declined. We were faced with the responsibility ourselves; we had not the support of the gentlemen on the other side, while the country was getting into a state of chaos—

Speaker.hpid: MR. DE VALERA MR. DE VALERA
Speaker.P: That is not so.

Speaker.hpid: PRESIDENT GRIFFITH PRESIDENT GRIFFITH
Speaker.P: We had not the active support of the other side; they declined to act on the Committee. By the vote of Dáil Eireann the Treaty was approved. The Provisional Government has come into being. The Provisional Government has taken over the various Departments and amongst other things it must take over police. That is the policy to be pursued—to take over and form a police force. We cannot, as Dáil Eireann, form a police force. We have not enough money to form a police force that would run for three weeks. But the Provisional Government can do it and has the money. The Minister for Home Affairs has been endeavouring to establish a police force that would function until Mr. de Valera's side or our side would win at the elections, and the responsibility would then rest on the winning side.

Speaker.hpid: MISS MACSWINEY MISS MACSWINEY
Speaker.P: Will the Minister for Home Affairs give an undertaking that he will not employ in the police force any man, or any body of men, who has or have taken a part against the Irish people, in the recent, or the present war. Can we get an answer definitely that any such man as this Kearney is employed by him in any capacity which he holds as an Irishman?

Speaker.hpid: PRESIDENT GRIFFITH PRESIDENT GRIFFITH
Speaker.P: Men remained in the R.I.C. during the recent war at our request.

Speaker.hpid: MISS MACSWINEY MISS MACSWINEY
Speaker.P: Kearney is not one of them.

Speaker.hpid: PRESIDENT GRIFFITH PRESIDENT GRIFFITH
Speaker.P: There were men who offered to resign. I got at least one thousand applications from men who were willing to resign if we could help them out. They were quite willing to help us.

Speaker.hpid: MISS MACSWINEY MISS MACSWINEY
Speaker.P: Is this man Kearney in that category?

Speaker.hpid: PRESIDENT GRIFFITH PRESIDENT GRIFFITH
Speaker.P: I do not know who Kearney is. But I know that the question of Kearney is raised only for one purpose.

Speaker.hpid: MR. F. LYNCH MR. F. LYNCH
Speaker.P: In speaking of matters of that sort can we be told who thrust a bayonet through the photograph of Casement in the Volunteer Hall at Cork in Easter Week, 1916?

Speaker.hpid: MISS MACSWINEY MISS MACSWINEY
Speaker.P: He was recently offered a position in the Free State police force.

Speaker.hpid: THE ACTING SPEAKER THE ACTING SPEAKER
Speaker.P: This matter is entirely out of order.

Speaker.hpid: MR. W.T. COSGRAVE MR. W.T. COSGRAVE
Speaker.P: Those who are against the Government of the day, and who have been all the time standing for the functioning of Dáil Eireann, now have reversed their positions and are proceeding to mark their idea of the progress of the Dáil Departments by the reducing of the vote by one thousand pounds. That seems very strange. I do not know where that comes in. No mention has been made as to what particular item has to be reduced. We have heard question after question. Now, I think the President ought to know what it would cost to maintain a police force of three or four thousand men in this country, and whether or not the funds of the Dáil are sufficient to bear that cost. The essence of the opposition here is to influence and to control, as far as they can, the activities of the Provisional Government. They say they won't go into the City Hall or speak to us while we are there, and yet they come here to seek to influence our conduct of affairs.

Speaker.hpid: MR. M.P. COLIVET MR. M.P. COLIVET
Speaker.P: I have asked what is the Dáil going to do in this matter? Does it mean that the Dáil is going to remain in the position of marking time? Is the Dáil to remain stagnant on the question of establishing a police force? The Dáil has sufficient money in hands to do it very well, and if they have not, they have means of getting more. That is the way for the Dáil to function and not allow it to be subverted by the Provisional Government.

Speaker.hpid: DR. P. FERRAN DR. P. FERRAN
Speaker.P: Some County Councils have offered to strike a rate to maintain a police force, and they have been obstructed from doing so by the Minister of Local Government.

Speaker.hpid: MR. COSGRAVE MR. COSGRAVE
Speaker.P: The gentleman who has spoken knows as much about Local Government finance as he does about the moon. I know well what he is talking about. What is the use of talking rubbish? You have no authority to strike a rate for a police force, and it is a dishonest thing to do it, if you attempt to do it. You have adopted the regulations in force up to a certain date, and you would not have any right under them to strike any money for a police force.

Speaker.hpid: DR. P. FERRAN DR. P. FERRAN
Speaker.P: You have power to amend the regulations.

Speaker.hpid: MR. W.T. COSGRAVE MR. W.T. COSGRAVE
Speaker.P: This is the sixth speech——

Speaker.hpid: PRESIDENT GRIFFITH PRESIDENT GRIFFITH
Speaker.P: Is it in order that the Deputy for Monaghan should speak more than once?

Speaker.hpid: MR. S. MACENTEE MR. S. MACENTEE
Speaker.P: I am now speaking on the amendment (cries of “Chair”).

Speaker.hpid: THE ACTING SPEAKER THE ACTING SPEAKER
Speaker.P: I will have to ask you not to continue.

Speaker.hpid: MR. S. MACENTEE MR. S. MACENTEE
Speaker.P: But am I not entitled?

Speaker.hpid: THE ACTING SPEAKER THE ACTING SPEAKER
Speaker.P: I will have to rule you out of order.

Speaker.hpid: MR. S. MACENTEE MR. S. MACENTEE
Speaker.P: Can I not speak to the amendment?

Speaker.hpid: THE ACTING SPEAKER THE ACTING SPEAKER
Speaker.P: You are ruled out of order.

Speaker.hpid: MR. S. MACENTEE MR. S. MACENTEE
Speaker.P: On a point of order, I was speaking to a fresh amendment for the first time and you rule me out of order.

Speaker.hpid: THE ACTING SPEAKER THE ACTING SPEAKER
Speaker.P: The discussion is now on the Estimates.

Speaker.hpid: MR. S. MACENTEE MR. S. MACENTEE
Speaker.P: The discussion arises on a fresh amendment. Do you rule me out of order?

Speaker.hpid: THE ACTING SPEAKER THE ACTING SPEAKER
Speaker.P: Yes in this case. I rule you out of order as obstructing the House in its business.

Speaker.hpid: MR. S. MACENTEE MR. S. MACENTEE
Speaker.P: No, not obstructing.

Speaker.hpid: MR. A. STACK MR. A. STACK
Speaker.P: Certainly not. That is bias if you like.

Speaker.hpid: MR. S. MACENTEE MR. S. MACENTEE
Speaker.P: That ruling is most unfair. I am rising on a fresh amendment to speak for the first time.

Speaker.hpid: THE ACTING SPEAKER THE ACTING SPEAKER
Speaker.P: I rule you out as obstructing the House.

Speaker.hpid: MR. S. MACENTEE MR. S. MACENTEE
Speaker.P: I ask my comrades in the House to protect me. You are depriving me of my rights and privileges as a member of the House.

Speaker.hpid: MR. KEVIN O'HIGGINS MR. KEVIN O'HIGGINS
Speaker.P: I have been wondering whether I would be in order in proposing an increase of £500,000 in the Estimates of the Minister of Home Affairs to allow him to develop a police force adequate to the requirements of the situation, under Dáil Eireann. It seems to me that we have to take our bearings now. This morning I suggested, if we were up against a definite issue, that the Provisional Government was set up by a meeting composed of the members elected to constituencies in Southern Ireland, and that it is responsible to that body and not to Dáil Eireann. I said I, as one member of the Provisional Government, would stand by that, and in the things I do in my capacity of what certain members would call national apostate, I refuse to be responsible to this body. That is the full, unsatisfactory state of affairs. The position is vague, undefined and anomalous; but in so far as it is unsatisfactory and anomalous, the responsibility lies on those who put every difficulty in the way of seeking from the people of Ireland a straight declaration of whether or not they wished us to proceed on the basis of the Treaty (hear, hear).

Speaker.hpid: MR. G. GAVAN DUFFY MR. G. GAVAN DUFFY
Speaker.P: The time has come when we might pass on from this business.

Speaker.hpid: MR. D. CEANNT MR. D. CEANNT
Speaker.P: My motion is before the House.

Speaker.hpid: MR. G. GAVAN DUFFY MR. G. GAVAN DUFFY
Speaker.P: We could easily avoid this unsatisfactory kind of debate if there was a little less of what I will charitably call muddle on the opposite side. Two questions have been raised—the report of Ministers and the case of Mr. Kearney. If it is desired to raise at the meeting of the Dáil an important matter of policy, it surely would be the obvious course to give a notice to the Minister concerned. In this case it is manifestly unfair to expect Ministers who have been in office something like seven weeks to prepare reports. It would be absurd to ask them to prepare reports on their work during that period. The right way to obtain information is to ask beforehand so that the Minister could prepare an answer. The second thing is a vote of censure about this man Kearney, but the notion that the Minister for Home Affairs can deal with that on the minute is perfectly absurd. The suggestion to reduce a vote upon a question sprung on the Minister like that is one that should not recommend itself to the House. The Standing Orders give you ample means of dealing with an unsatisfactory answer. You have all this now sprung on the House. That is not the best way to deal with public business. After the agreement at the Ard-Fheis it is rather unfortunate that these matters should develop into a mere party question. That is the effect of bringing up matters without notice. I propose the vote be now taken.

Speaker.hpid: MR. DE VALERA MR. DE VALERA
Speaker.P: If the Ministers give a report to the House which can be discussed, that is the place to bring up the question of policy. If we have not it that way we must have it in the Estimates. I hold it is the Minister is responsible for not bringing up the matter in the usual fashion.

Speaker.hpid: THE ACTING SPEAKER THE ACTING SPEAKER
Speaker.P: We have now the amendment proposed by Mr. Ceannt to the effect that the vote be reduced by one thousand pounds. I will now put this to the House.
The amendment was put.

Speaker.hpid: THE ACTING SPEAKER THE ACTING SPEAKER
Speaker.P: I declare the amendment defeated.

Speaker.hpid: MR. DE VALERA MR. DE VALERA
Speaker.P: I beg to move as an amendment: “That we postpone consideration of the Estimate for Home Affairs until we have a report from the Minister of that Department, and a detailed statement of his policy for the maintenance of public order during the period that must elapse before the Irish people have expressed their will in the elections.”

Speaker.hpid: MR. ART O'CONNOR MR. ART O'CONNOR
Speaker.P: I beg to second the amendment. I am in thorough agreement with the President in that matter. There should be some sort of understanding between the two sides in the House as to how order is to be kept in the country, and this matter should be postponed until the Minister for Home Affairs has a statement.

Speaker.hpid: MR. W.T. COSGRAVE MR. W.T. COSGRAVE
Speaker.P: I have two points to raise. The mover of the amendment has spoken more times than he ought to, and therefore his amendment would be out of order. Now, number two point is that an amendment has already been negatived that you postpone the Estimates. The greater includes the less and it is now moved that the less be postponed. I submit the proposal goes by the board.

Speaker.hpid: MR. HARRY BOLAND MR. HARRY BOLAND
Speaker.P: I wish, on this very important point that we would consider things calmly. It is suggested, by some move I cannot fathom, that we on this side are not prepared to co-operate to maintain law and order.

Speaker.hpid: PRESIDENT GRIFFITH PRESIDENT GRIFFITH
Speaker.P: You refused the offer made at the last Session.

Speaker.hpid: MR. H. BOLAND MR. H. BOLAND
Speaker.P: So far as I know, we on this side of the House are as anxious to preserve law and order in the country as you are on your side, and if an opportunity be given this House to discuss the best method whereby law and order may be maintained, an unfortunate division on this matter would not arise. Do you not consider it right and proper that an opportunity would be given in Public Session so that the people of the country would see that we are all determined to preserve law and order, in so far as we can? The cause of unrest is because there has been no order to express what has been the unanimous opinion of this House—that law and order must be maintained. I submit to the gentlemen on the opposite side that an opportunity should be given to us on this side to demonstrate that we, as well as they, are determined to preserve order.

Speaker.hpid: MR. MICHAEL COLLINS MR. MICHAEL COLLINS
Speaker.P: We gave it to you and we know how you treated it.

Speaker.hpid: MR. DE VALERA MR. DE VALERA
Speaker.P: I did not intend to make any speech on this amendment. One thing is to ask us to co-operate under a policy with which we do not agree. That is, the policy of the majority party in this House. Another matter is that when they have decided their policy and got a majority in favour of a certain line of action, that we are not to get an opportunity as members to, at least, get the country to benefit by that policy. Have we no opportunity now to say that such benefits as might accrue to the country should come from the policy of the opposite side? I think it is ridiculous. We will not co-operate in the sense of taking part responsibility with the majority party here for the maintenance of order, or for their policy. But their policy has got a majority here, and it is our business as part of the whole House to see that that policy which they have got a majority for is carried out, and to criticise if it is not carried out. And we have a definite right to know what provision is going to be made in accordance with their policy, by the Minister for Home Affairs, for the maintenance of public order in the country. If the majority rule—and we have accepted that, because we would not be here if we had not—we have the right still of demanding that that majority gives an account of its stewardship, not merely to the members here, but to the country as a whole. We have a right to demand that the Minister for Home Affairs would tell us what provision has been made in accordance with the policy of the majority, for the maintenance of order.

Speaker.hpid: MR. LORCAN ROBBINS MR. LORCAN ROBBINS
Speaker.P: The Deputy for Kilkenny asked for a ruling.

Speaker.hpid: THE ACTING SPEAKER THE ACTING SPEAKER

Speaker.hpid: THE ACTING SPEAKER THE ACTING SPEAKER
Speaker.P: I must declare Mr. de Valera's amendment defeated.
The voting was 44 for, and 55 against.

Speaker.hpid: MR. JOSEPH MACGUINNESS MR. JOSEPH MACGUINNESS
Speaker.P: I propose that the motion for the adoption of the Estimates be now put.

Speaker.hpid: DR. VINCENT WHITE DR. VINCENT WHITE
Speaker.P: I beg to second that.

Speaker.hpid: MR. DE VALERA MR. DE VALERA
Speaker.P: Might we speak on this? (“No!”).

Speaker.hpid: THE ACTING SPEAKER THE ACTING SPEAKER
Speaker.P: Not after Mr. MacGuinness.

Speaker.hpid: MR. DE VALERA MR. DE VALERA
Speaker.P: Well, I must protest strongly against the Estimates for the half-year being put without discussion. It was never done before, even in war-time.

Speaker.hpid: MR. AUSTIN STACK MR. AUSTIN STACK
Speaker.P: We have merely discussed the Home Affairs Department, and we have not had a single question with regard to Local Government, Labour, Secretariat, Trade and Commerce, Publicity, Finance, Foreign Affairs, Economics, Trustees, President's Office, Boycott or Defence. They have not yet been dealt with, and you accept a motion now in spite of protest.

Speaker.hpid: MR. MICHAEL COLLINS MR. MICHAEL COLLINS
Speaker.P: On a point of order. Must not that motion be put without amendment or discussion according to Standing Orders?

Speaker.hpid: THE ACTING SPEAKER THE ACTING SPEAKER
Speaker.P: I am following the Standing Orders strictly, and I have no option. The Standing Orders are that when it is moved “that the question be now put,” it shall be put and decided without amendment or debate.

Speaker.hpid: MR. SEAN MACENTEE MR. SEAN MACENTEE
Speaker.P: It is a direct violation of the compact at the Dáil. This Dáil was to function in all its Departments, and one of its privileges is criticism of the Ministry.

Speaker.hpid: CATHAL BRUGHA CATHAL BRUGHA
Speaker.P: There is one particular Department which concerns me.

Speaker.hpid: MR. WILLIAM SEARS MR. WILLIAM SEARS
Speaker.P: I rise to a point of order.

Speaker.hpid: MR. J.N. DOLAN MR. J.N. DOLAN
Speaker.P: I do not think this is in order. Is it in order or not, Mr. Speaker?

Speaker.hpid: CATHAL BRUGHA CATHAL BRUGHA
Speaker.P: It is estimated it will cost £80,000 for Special Work for the Defence Department for the next six months. I have some experience of the Defence Department, and before you put this I would like to know exactly what is this work?

Speaker.hpid: THE ACTING SPEAKER THE ACTING SPEAKER
Speaker.P: In order to preserve the rights of the minority— every individual has rights here—and still keep by the Standing Orders, I would suggest that these matters be put in writing and handed to the Ministers, and the Ministers will have to reply to them in due course. But I must insist now in carrying out the Standing Orders. It has been moved that the question be now put. Does anyone challenge a division?

Speaker.hpid: MR. COSGRAVE MR. COSGRAVE
Speaker.P: I challenge a division. Are they for or against the Estimates? The public should know.

Speaker.hpid: MR. AUSTIN STACK MR. AUSTIN STACK
Speaker.P: Mr. Cosgrave's policy—stifle discussion.

Speaker.hpid: MR. W.T. COSGRAVE MR. W.T. COSGRAVE
Speaker.P: You are now going to be put in the position of voting against the Estimates. That is where we will put you.

Speaker.hpid: MR. HARRY BOLAND MR. HARRY BOLAND
Speaker.P: This side calls for a division only as a protest against the rushing of the Estimates.

Speaker.hpid: MISS M. MACSWINEY MISS M. MACSWINEY
Speaker.P: I would like to point out—— (cries of “Call the names”).

Speaker.hpid: MR. DE VALERA MR. DE VALERA
Speaker.P: I am against the Estimates because they are rushed in a most scandalous fashion. The usual reports were supplied even in wartime, when we had several batches of typewritten reports from the Ministers. Here we have not had that, and the Estimates are being rushed because the Ministry are in a majority.

Speaker.hpid: THE ACTING SPEAKER THE ACTING SPEAKER
Speaker.P: Do you challenge a division?

Speaker.hpid: MR. COSGRAVE MR. COSGRAVE
Speaker.P: Yes.

Speaker.hpid: THE ACTING SPEAKER THE ACTING SPEAKER
Speaker.P: I declare the motion to have the question put, carried by fifty-two to forty-four. Now we will put the motion that the Estimates be adopted.

Speaker.hpid: MR. W.T. COSGRAVE MR. W.T. COSGRAVE
Speaker.P: I demand a division. Let the public know who are for or against the Estimates.

Speaker.hpid: DR. PATRICK MACCARTAN DR. PATRICK MACCARTAN
Speaker.P: If the present Ministers should have sent in a report, the former Ministers should have sent in a report up to the time they left office.

Speaker.hpid: MR. DE VALERA MR. DE VALERA
Speaker.P: We have not been asked to do it.

Speaker.hpid: MR. W.T. COSGRAVE MR. W.T. COSGRAVE
Speaker.P: I demand a division.

Speaker.hpid: MR. DE VALERA MR. DE VALERA
Speaker.P: It will really be the same voting.

Speaker.hpid: MR. W.T. COSGRAVE MR. W.T. COSGRAVE
Speaker.P: Very well; I am satisfied.

Speaker.hpid: THE ACTING SPEAKER THE ACTING SPEAKER
Speaker.P: I declare the Estimates carried on the last figures, fifty-two to forty-four. Does anyone move the adjournment?

Speaker.hpid: MR. FRANK FAHY MR. FRANK FAHY
Speaker.P: I propose the House adjourns for twelve months. There is no use in being here.

Speaker.hpid: CATHAL BRUGHA CATHAL BRUGHA
Speaker.P: I suppose it is for the purpose of maintaining unity all this thing is gone on with.

Speaker.hpid: THE ACTING SPEAKER THE ACTING SPEAKER
Speaker.P: I declare the House adjourned until eleven o'clock to-morrow.
The Dáil adjourned.
